properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Dominion City
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-12-05T12:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-12-04T12:32:24-06:00, 179D94AF-83C2-D77A-4EC4-C03C8B6F5932
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For The Village Of Pleasantdale
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for Village of Pleasantdale. This advisory is for the Village of Pleasantdale and for any individuals who may access water the Pleasantdale water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2019-12-11T16:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Pleasantdale, 2019-12-04T09:27:17-06:00, 3547EED1-FC36-BFED-9CEC-35FB97BD4F64
Area: Village of Pleasantdale
properties.Author: SK Pleasantdale

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues today. Locations: Eagle River and the Strait. Time span: continuing until this evening. Total Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Remarks: Areas along the coast from Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair are likely to see less accumulation as the snow is expected to be wet and mix with ice pellets and freezing rain. However, areas inland along the Trans Labrador Highway could see up to 15 cm. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-05T01:07:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T09:08:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3581403628.2019
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lasting blizzard conditions, with visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow, are expected to develop by this evening. Although the visibility may intermittently improve, the hazardous conditions are forecast to persist into Friday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-05T09:20:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T17:21:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2502543164.2019
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible tonight into Thursday morning. Lake effect snow is expected through the day with local snowfall accumulations of 2 to 5 cm possible by this evening. As colder air moves over Lake Huron late in the afternoon, snow squalls are likely to affect the area beginning this evening. Local snowfall accumulations may reach 10 to 15 cm by Thursday morning in the heaviest snow squalls. Gusty northwest winds will also lead to local blowing snow with these snow squalls. The snow squalls will begin to weaken Thursday morning, with additional accumulations of 2 to 4 cm possible by Thursday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-05T07:44:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T15:45:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0611483749.2019
Area: Guelph - Erin - Southern Wellington County, Kitchener - Cambridge - Region of Waterloo
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A slow moving frontal system over B.C. will exit the province today. Heavy snowfall associated with this storm will end this afternoon. Total snowfall accumulations of up to 40 cm are expected for this event. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-05T04:32:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T18:21:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2691791285.2019
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible late this afternoon into Thursday morning. Lake effect snow, at times heavy, is expected through the day today with local snowfall accumulations of 5 cm possible by this evening. As colder air moves over Georgian Bay late in the afternoon or evening, more intense snow squalls will develop tonight. Snowfall accumulations up to 15 cm are possible by Thursday morning in the heaviest snow squalls. Gusty northwest winds will also lead to local blowing snow with these snow squalls. The snow squalls will begin to weaken Thursday morning, with additional accumulations of 5 cm possible by Thursday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-05T07:42:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T15:43:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2360338337.2019
Area: Uxbridge - Beaverton - Northern Durham Region, Newmarket - Georgina - Northern York Region, Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Innisfil - New Tecumseth - Angus
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected to develop this afternoon into Thursday morning. Lake effect snow, at times heavy, is expected through the day with local snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm possible by this evening. As colder air moves over Lake Huron late in the afternoon, more intense snow squalls will develop. Local snowfall accumulations may reach 15 cm by Thursday morning in the heaviest snow squalls. Gusty northwest winds will also lead to local blowing snow with these snow squalls. The snow squalls will begin to weaken Thursday morning, with additional accumulations of 5 cm possible by Thursday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm continues. A frontal system over southern B.C. will move into the US this evening. While most areas in the region will see a mixture of rain and snow for the rest of today, another 10 cm of snow is expected over higher terrain. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-05T03:59:06-00:00
